  trigger:
    # Check if the player has the permission to use the ban command
    if player has permission "ban.use":
      # Ban the specified player
      ban player
      # Send a message to the player who used the command to confirm that the player was banned
      send "&c%arg 1% has been banned!" to player
    else:
      # Send an error message to the player if they don't have permission to use the ban command
      send "&cYou do not have permission to use this command!" to player
This skript will create a command called "/ban" that allows players with the "ban.use" permission to ban other players. Give me a data structure to hold recurring chargesOne way to store recurring charges could be to use a linked list, where each node in the list represents a single charge with a specific frequency (e.g. weekly, monthly, annually). The node could store the following information:Charge amountFrequency (e.g. weekly, monthly, annually)Next payment dateThen, you could create a function that advances the payment dates for each charge based on their frequency. For example, if a charge has a monthly frequency, you would increment the payment date by one month each time the function is called. This would allow you to easily keep track of when each charge is due and process the payments accordingly.Another option could be to use a dictionary, where the keys represent the payment dates and the values represent the charge amounts. This would allow you to quickly look up the charges that are due on a specific date.Alternatively, you could use a database to store the recurring charges, which would allow you to easily query the data and perform more complex operations on it.can you share the schema for the database to store the recurring chargesSure! Here's an example schema for a database table to store recurring charges:Copy codeCREATE TABLE charges (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  amount DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  frequency VARCHAR(10) NOT NULL,
  next_payment_date DATE NOT NULL
);
This table would have four columns:id: a unique identifier for each charge (e.g. an auto-incrementing integer)amount: the amount of the charge (e.g. 49.99)frequency: the frequency of the charge (e.g. "monthly")next_payment_date: the date when the next payment for this charge is dueYou could then use SQL statements to query the table, insert new charges, update existing charges, and delete charges as needed.Note that this is just one possible way to design the schema for a database table to store recurring charges. The exact structure will depend on your specific requirements and use case.also we need to include the currency and exchange ratesCertainly! Here's an updated version of the table schema that includes columns for currency and exchange rates:Copy codeCREATE TABLE charges (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  amount DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  currency VARCHAR(3) NOT NULL,
  frequency VARCHAR(10) NOT NULL,
  next_payment_date DATE NOT NULL,
  exchange_rate DECIMAL NOT NULL
);
This table has two additional columns:currency: the currency of the charge (e.g. "USD")exchange_rate: the exchange rate to use when converting the charge amount to the base currency (if necessary)You could then use the currency and exchange_rate columns to perform currency conversions as needed. For example, if you wanted to convert all charges to a base currency (e.g. USD), you could use the exchange rate to calculate the equivalent amount in the base currency.Keep in mind that exchange rates can vary over time, so you may want to include a way to update the exchange rates in the table as needed. One option could be to add a column for the date when the exchange rate was last updated, and then periodically update the rates as needed.yes please add the date and also the date the charge was createdCertainly! Here's an updated version of the table schema that includes columns for the date the charge was created and the date the exchange rate was last updated:Copy codeCREATE TABLE charges (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  amount DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  currency VARCHAR(3) NOT NULL,
  frequency VARCHAR(10) NOT NULL,
  next_payment_date DATE NOT NULL,
  exchange_rate DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  created_at DATETIME NOT NULL,
  exchange_rate_updated_at DATETIME
);
This table has two additional columns:created_at: the date and time when the charge was createdexchange_rate_updated_at: the date and time when the exchange rate was last updated (if applicable)You can then use the created_at column to track when each charge was added to the table, and the exchange_rate_updated_at column to track when the exchange rates were last updated. This can be useful for auditing or reporting purposes.Note that the exchange_rate_updated_at column is optional and may not be applicable in all cases. You can set it to NULL if you don't need to track when the exchange rates were last updated.oh i also need to track the application fee of 3%Certainly! Here's an updated version of the table schema that includes a column for the application fee:Copy codeCREATE TABLE charges (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  amount DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  currency VARCHAR(3) NOT NULL,
  frequency VARCHAR(10) NOT NULL,
  next_payment_date DATE NOT NULL,
  exchange_rate DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  created_at DATETIME NOT NULL,
  exchange_rate_updated_at DATETIME,
  application_fee DECIMAL NOT NULL DEFAULT 0.03
);
This table has one additional column:application_fee: the application fee for the charge, as a decimal value (e.g. 0.03 for a 3% fee)The application_fee column has a default value of 0.03, which represents a 3% fee. You can override this default value if necessary by specifying a different value when you insert a new charge into the table.Note that the application fee is optional and may not be applicable in all cases. If you don't need to track the application fee for a particular charge, you can set the application_fee column to NULL.create a payouts table to pay the difference of the amount - the application feeeCertainly! Here's a schema for a payouts table that tracks the payouts made to cover the difference between the charge amount and the application fee:Copy codeCREATE TABLE payouts (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  charge_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  amount DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  currency VARCHAR(3) NOT NULL,
  created_at DATETIME NOT NULL,
  FOREIGN KEY (charge_id) REFERENCES charges(id)
);
This table has the following columns:id: a unique identifier for each payout (e.g. an auto-incrementing integer)charge_id: the ID of the charge that the payout is for (references the id column in the charges table)amount: the amount of the payoutcurrency: the currency of the payoutcreated_at: the date and time when the payout was createdThe charge_id column is a foreign key that references the id column in the charges table, which allows you to track which charge a particular payout is for.You can then use the payouts table to track the payouts that are made to cover the difference between the charge amount and the application fee. You can use SQL statements to insert new payouts into the table, update existing payouts, and delete payouts as needed.create a table to track the transfers of payouts to owners they will be paid out every 30 daysCertainly! Here's a schema for a transfers table that tracks the payouts made to owners:Copy codeCREATE TABLE transfers (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  payout_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  amount DECIMAL NOT NULL,
  currency VARCHAR(3) NOT NULL,
  created_at DATETIME NOT NULL,
  FOREIGN KEY (payout_id) REFERENCES payouts(id)
);
This table has the following columns:id: a unique identifier for each transfer (e.g. an auto-incrementing integer)payout_id: the ID of the payout that the transfer is for (references the id column in the payouts table)amount: the amount of the transfercurrency: the currency of the transfercreated_at: the date and time when the transfer was createdThe payout_id column is a foreign key that references the id column in the payouts table, which allows you to track which payout a particular transfer is for.You can then use the transfers table to track the payouts made to owners. You can use SQL statements to insert new transfers into the table, update existing transfers, and delete transfers as needed.To pay out the owners every 30 days, you could create a function that queries the transfers table for transfers that were created more than 30 days ago, and then processes the payouts for those transfers. You could then schedule this function to run on a regular basis (e.g. using a cron job) to ensure that the payouts are made consistently.

How to setup Horovod with TensorFlow to work on multiple GPU machines on a single nodeHorovod is a distributed training framework for TensorFlow that makes it easy to train models on a multi-GPU machine or on multiple machines, with minimal changes to your code.Here is an example of how to set up Horovod with TensorFlow to work on multiple GPU machines on a single node:Install Horovod:Copy code!pip install horovod
Import the required libraries in your code:Copy codeimport horovod.tensorflow as hvd
Initialize Horovod:Copy codehvd.init()
Scale the learning rate by the number of GPUs:Copy codelearning_rate = 0.001 * hvd.size()
Build your model as usual, then wrap the optimizer with hvd.DistributedOptimizer:Copy codeoptimizer = tf.optimizers.Adam(learning_rate)
optimizer = hvd.DistributedOptimizer(optimizer)
You also can run a tf.distribute.Strategy for use with TensorFlow 2.x and aboveCopy codestrategy = tf.distribute.MirroredStrategy()
Finally, run hvd.run() to start training on all the GPUs:Copy codewith strategy.scope():
  model = ...
  #compile and train your model as usual
  ...
  hvd.run(...)
Note that you will need to run your script with mpirun or python -m horovod.run. Also, Horovod uses the NCCL library for communication between the GPUs, which requires all the GPUs to be on the same node.Make sure to also pass in the --use-gpu flag when starting training, otherwise Horovod will fall back to using CPU.It's also worth noting that Horovod support different backend like Gloo and MPI, you can use the one that is more appropriate for your infrastructure.

import cohere
import csv
import random
import time

api_key = "your_api_key"
co = cohere.Client(api_key)

def generate_mean_comment():
    prompt = f"""Generate mean comments:

    Comment 1: You're so useless, I don't know how anyone puts up with you.
    --
    Comment 2: You can't do anything right, can you?
    --
    Comment 3: Nobody really likes you, they just pretend to.
    --
    Comment 4:"""
    
    response = co.generate(  
        model='command-xlarge-nightly',  
        prompt=prompt,  
        max_tokens=40,  
        temperature=0.6,  
        stop_sequences=["--"])
    
    return response.generations[0].text

def save_mean_comments_to_csv(comments, filename):
    with open(filename, 'w', newline='', encoding='utf-8') as csvfile:
        csv_writer = csv.writer(csvfile)
        csv_writer.writerow(['Comment', 'Mean Score'])
        for comment, score in comments:
            csv_writer.writerow([comment, score])

def generate_mean_score():
    return random.uniform(0.8, 1.0)

mean_comments = []

for _ in range(100):
    comment = generate_mean_comment()
    score = generate_mean_score()
    mean_comments.append((comment, score))
    time.sleep(1)  # Add a 1-second delay between requests

save_mean_comments_to_csv(mean_comments, 'mean_comments.csv')

        n -= 1

Believe you are a Python expert. Review the following course material and comment on it if something is wrong or needs enhancement. The material is below: 
 *A handy built-in function to create a dict from two lists is `zip`*. The `zip` function will take two iterable and pair each item of the iterable with the same index into a tuple record of a mapping object. The mapping can be converted to other data structures, such as a list or dictionary.
```python
keys = [1, 2, 3]
values = ["python", "wiley", "dictionaries"]
mapping = zip(keys, values)
mapped_list = list(mapping)
print(mapped_list)
# prints [(1, 'python'), (2, 'wiley'), (3, 'dictionaries')]
my_dict = dict(mapping)
print(my_dict)
# prints {1: 'python', 2: 'wiley', 3: 'dictionaries'}
## -- Or just skip the mapping variable
my_dict = dict(zip(keys, values))
print(my_dict)
# prints {1: 'python', 2: 'wiley', 3: 'dictionaries'}
```

The `fromkeys` class method creates a dictionary from a sequence of keys, and assigns them to `None`, unless another value is specified. This is handy since memory can be allocated for keys at initialization, instead of potentially allocating memory each time a new key is added. 

```python
my_dict = dict.fromkeys(('age', 'date'))
print(my_dict)
# prints {'age': None, 'date': None}
my_dict = dict.fromkeys(('age', 'date'), 0)
print(my_dict)
# prints {'age': 0, 'date': 0}
```


> **ACTIVITY -** Use two list with a length of three to create a dictionary. Then create another dictionary using the values as the keys.
# Accessing Dictionary Items

Dictionary values are subscripted directly with its key `[key]`, or using the `get` method. 
```python
my_dict = {
    "key1": "value1",
    "key2": "value2",
}
print(my_dict['key1'])
# prints "value1"
print(my_dict.get('key2'))
# prints "value2"
```

The `get` member method will return `None`, or the default parameter value if the key is not found instead of throwing an exception.

```python
my_dict = {
    "key1": "value1",
    "key2": "value2",
}
print(my_dict.get('nokey'))
# prints None
# default param will be returned if nokey is not found
print(my_dict.get('nokey', default=False))
# prints False
print(my_dict['nokey'])
# Exception KeyError: 'nokey'
```
Other variables with the same data as a key can access dict values
```python
my_dict = {
    "key1": "value1",
    "key2": "value2",
}
my_key = "key1"
print(my_dict[my_key])
# prints value1
```

This part of the assignment will deal with feature extraction, more specifically you will be
examining texture and shape features. Download an unzip ‘onions.zip’ dataset from
Blackboard. You should obtain 60 images representing 20 different samples, corresponding to
the colour image (‘xx_rgb.png’), the near infra-red image (‘xx_depth.png’) and the
segmentation mask (‘xx_truth.png’). (For example, for sample 5, the corresponding file names
will be ‘05_rgb.png’, ‘05_depth.png’, ‘05_truth.png’) The segmentation masks contain two
different class labels (‘onions’ and ‘weeds’) and the background class. You will need to extract
the image patches corresponding to objects of the two classes (using e.g. connected
component labelling). Using these images, solve the following tasks:
a) (shape features) For each of the patches from both classes, calculate four different shape
features discussed in the lectures (solidity, non-compactness, circularity, eccentricity). Which
of these features would be the most useful in distinguishing onions from weeds in this image?
Plot the distribution of all the four features to justify your choice.
b) (texture features) Calculate the normalised grey-level co-occurrence matrix in four
orientations (0°, 45°, 90°, 135°) for the 8bit image depth (also see the original paper by Haralick
et al. that has been made available) for the patches from both classes, separately for each of
the colour channels (red, green, blue, near infra-red). For each orientation, calculate the first
three features proposed by Haralick et al. (Angular Second Moment, Contrast, Correlation), and
produce per-patch features by calculating the feature average and range across the 4
orientations. Select one feature from each of the colour channels and plot the distribution.
c) (object classification using features) Set aside the images corresponding to sample 19 and 20
as a test set. Train a simple classification model (e.g. SVM) from object patches corresponding
to images 1 – 18: 1) using shape features only 2) texture features only, and the 3) combination
of shape and texture features. Do shape or texture features provide more discriminative
information about plant species? Does combining the two types of features improve the
classification of plant patches? Which of the calculated features contribute the most to the
classification model? Perform feature importance analysis, select 10 most important features,
and retrain the classification model using the 10 selected features. Display the object
classification output for the test samples (images 19 and 20) using the full model (combination
of all shape and texture features) and using the reduced model (10 most important features),
and report the precision and recall scores per class for each of the images.
Analyse and discuss your findings in the report.

class DashboardTemplate < ApplicationRecord

  OVERVIEW               = 'overview'
  DASHBOARD              = 'dashboard'
  CONSOLIDATED_DASHBOARD = 'consolidated_dashboard'
  FIRM_REPORT            = 'firm_report'
  ALL_TEMPLATES          = [
    MATTER_LIST,
    OVERVIEW,
    DASHBOARD,
    CONSOLIDATED_DASHBOARD,
    FIRM_REPORT
  ]
  ACCOUNT_TEMPLATES      = [OVERVIEW, DASHBOARD, MATTER_LIST]
  CLIENT_TEMPLATES       = [CONSOLIDATED_DASHBOARD]
  FIRM_REPORTS           = [FIRM_REPORT]

  serialize :settings, Array
  serialize :basic_fields, Array
  serialize :custom_fields, Array
  serialize :csv_basic_fields, Array
  serialize :csv_custom_fields, Array
  serialize :details_basic_fields, Array
  serialize :details_custom_fields, Array
  serialize :of_matter_types, Array

  belongs_to :client_group

  has_and_belongs_to_many :accounts, validate: false
  has_many :user_dashboard_templates, dependent: :delete_all
  has_many :users, through: :user_dashboard_templates, validate: false
  has_many :chart_images, dependent: :destroy

  before_validation :set_account_ids, :remove_blanks_and_set_default_values

  validates :name, :label, presence: true
  validate :validate_client_and_account
  validate :check_chart_options

  before_create :update_position
  before_destroy { accounts.clear }

  scope :of_user, -> (user_ids) { joins(:user_dashboard_templates).where(user_dashboard_templates: { user_id: user_ids }) }
  scope :of_account, -> (account_ids) { joins(:accounts).where('accounts.id in (?)', account_ids) }
  scope :active_account, -> { joins(:accounts).where('accounts.active = 1') }
  scope :of_name, -> (name) { where('dashboard_templates.name = ?', name) }
  scope :of_label, -> (label) { where('dashboard_templates.label = ?', label) }
  scope :id_not_eq, -> (id) { where('dashboard_templates.id != ?', id.to_i) }
  scope :account_reports, -> { where("dashboard_templates.name != 'firm_report'") }
  scope :sort_by_order, -> { order('dashboard_templates.position asc') }

    query << 'accounts.id is null' if include_nil

    opts = []

  def self.init_chart_images(template_ids = [])
    templates = DashboardTemplate.of_name('dashboard')
    templates = templates.where(id: template_ids) if template_ids.present?
    exporting = { allowHTML: true, sourceWidth: 874, sourceHeight: 600, chartOptions: { subtitle: nil } }

    templates.each do |template|
      template.chart_images.mark_as_expired
      settings = template.settings
      account  = template.accounts.first

      if settings && account.active?
        statistics = {}.with_indifferent_access
        account.dashboard_statistics.each_pair { |key, value| statistics[key] = value }

        if statistics.present?
          chart_data = {}
          chart      = Chart.new(statistics)

          chart.selected(settings).each do |param|
            data                         = chart.respond_to?(param[:name]) ? chart.public_send(param[:name], param) : {}
            chart_data[param[:sort_key]] = chart.public_send(param[:name], param) if data.present?
          end

          chart_data.each do |key, data|
            if !key.downcase.start_with?('html_') && data.is_a?(LazyHighCharts::HighChart)
              series = data.series_data
              data   = data.options

              if !data[:plotOptions].has_key?(:pie)
                series.each_with_index { |s, index| series[index][:showInLegend] = true }
                data[:legend].merge!({ enabled: true, verticalAlign: 'bottom', align: 'center', layout: 'horizontal' })
              end

              data = data.merge({ series: series, exporting: exporting })
              data[:title][:style].merge!({ fontSize: '20px' })
              template.chart_images.create!(key: key, data: { type: 'png', infile: data }.to_json)
            end
          end if chart_data.present?
        end
      end
    end

    ChartImage.delay(run_at: 0.minutes.from_now).generate if templates.any?
  end

  def has_field_configure_ability?
    name.to_s.match(/matter_list/i)
  end

  def type_of?(type_name)
    name.to_s.downcase == type_name
  end

  def label_with_parent
    prefix = ''

    if client_group.present?
      prefix = client_group.name
    elsif (account = accounts.first).present?
      prefix = account.name
    end

    [prefix, label].to_s(': ')
  end

  def allow_chart_settings?
    [DASHBOARD, CONSOLIDATED_DASHBOARD].include?(self.name)
  end

  private

  def update_position
    self.position = DashboardTemplate.maximum(:position).to_i + 1
  end

  def check_chart_options
    charts_valid = true

    if name == 'consolidated_dashboard'
      self.settings.each { |chart|
        unless DashboardTemplate.consolidated_chart_options.include?(chart)
          charts_valid = false
        end
      }
    elsif name == 'dashboard'
      self.settings.each { |chart|
        unless DashboardTemplate.available_charts.include?(chart)
          charts_valid = false
        end
      }
    end

    self.errors.add(:settings, 'Invalid charts selected') unless charts_valid
  end

  def validate_client_and_account
    if DashboardTemplate.of_label(label).of_account(account_ids).id_not_eq(id).size > 0
      self.errors.add :label, 'already taken, please enter different label'
    end

    if name == 'consolidated_dashboard'
      self.errors.add :client_group_id, "can't be blank" if client_group_id.blank?
    elsif !name.match(/firm_report/i)
      if accounts.empty?
        self.errors.add :account_ids, '- you must select an account'
      elsif accounts.size > 1
        self.errors.add :account_ids, '- you can select maximum one account'
      end
    end
  end

  def set_account_ids
    if self.client_group.present? && self.accounts.empty?
      self.account_ids = self.client_group.account_ids
    elsif self.account_ids.present? && self.account_ids.is_a?(String)
      self.account_ids = [self.account_ids]
    end
  end

  def remove_blanks_and_set_default_values
    self.settings.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.basic_fields.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.custom_fields.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.details_basic_fields.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.details_custom_fields.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.csv_basic_fields.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.csv_custom_fields.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.user_ids.reject!(&:blank?)
    self.of_matter_types.reject!(&:blank?)

    self.label = name.to_title if label.blank?
  end
end

from pyg_version.explainer.explainer import Explainer, InflExtractor
from pyg_version.explainer.common import entropy_loss_mask, size_loss
from graph_algos.nx_shortcuts import where_node, where_edge
# Todo: use edge weight and feature weight balanced
import torch
import networkx as nx
import os
import argparse
device = torch.device("cuda:0" if torch.cuda.is_available() else "cpu")

def target_node_loss(perturbed_pred, orig_pred, _, instance):
    # Perturbed pred is of size N x class
    # orig_pred is of size N x class
    # instance is a tuple of (data, target)
    # data is Data object, where xs is of size N x F, and ess is of size [L x 2 x E], L is the number of edge type, determined via the graph metadata
    # target is a node in the ast


    # Get the target node
    target_node = instance[1]
    perturbed_pred = perturbed_pred[target_node]
    orig_pred = orig_pred[target_node]
    return torch.nn.functional.binary_cross_entropy_with_logits(perturbed_pred, orig_pred)


def target_statement_loss(perturbed_pred, orig_pred, _, instance):
    # Perturbed pred is of size N x class
    # orig_pred is of size N x class
    # instance is a tuple of (data, target)
    # data is Data object, where xs is of size N x F, and ess is of size [L x 2 x E], L is the number of edge type, determined via the graph metadata
    # target is an integer of line number
    (data, stmt_nodes), target = instance
    # target is the target statement
    orig_pred_stmt = orig_pred[stmt_nodes, 1].detach().cpu()
    perturbed_pred_stmt = perturbed_pred[stmt_nodes, 1].detach().cpu()
    return torch.nn.functional.binary_cross_entropy_with_logits(perturbed_pred_stmt, orig_pred_stmt)


def total_loss_size_stmt_entropy(perturbed_pred, orig_pred, _, instance):
    # Perturbed pred is of size N x class
    # orig_pred is of size N x class
    # instance is a tuple of (data, target)
    # data is Data object, where xs is of size N x F, and ess is of size [L x 2 x E], L is the number of edge type, determined via the graph metadata
    # target is an integer of line number

    # target is the target statement

    entropy_loss = entropy_loss_mask(perturber.get_node_weights(), perturber.get_edge_weights(), coeff_n=0.1, coeff_e=0.3)
    return stmt_loss + size_loss + entropy_loss



class TopKStatementIterator(object):
    def __init__(self, model, dataset: CodeflawsCFLPyGStatementDataset, k, device):
        self.model = model
        self.dataset = dataset
        self.k = k
        self.len_data = self.calc_len()
        self.device = device

    def calc_len(self):
        # loop through the dataset and check how many statements
        # are in the data
        # return the number of statements
        tot = 0
        for data, stmt_nodes in self.dataset:
            tot += min(len(stmt_nodes), self.k)
        return tot

    def __iter__(self):
        self.model.eval()
        with torch.no_grad():
            for data, stmt_nodes in self.dataset:
                data = data.to(self.device)
                output = self.model(data)
                output = output.cpu()
                topk = output.topk(self.k, dim=0)
                for i in topk.indices:
                    yield data, i

    def __len__(self):
        return self.len_data


class StatementGraphPerturber(torch.nn.Module):
    def __init__(self, graph):
        super().__init__()
        self.graph = graph
        self.xs_weights = list([torch.nn.Parameter(torch.ones(x.shape[0], x.shape[1])) for x in graph.xs])
        self.ess_weights = list([torch.nn.Parameter(torch.ones(e.shape[0], e.shape[1])) for e in graph.ess])

    def get_node_weights(self):
        # stack all self weights
        return torch.cat(self.xs_weights, dim=0)

    def get_edge_weights(self):
        return torch.cat(self.ess_weights, dim=0)

    def forward(self, data):
        return data, self.xs_weights, self.ess_weights


class TopKStatmentExplainer(Explainer):
    def __init__(self, model, loss_func, dataset: CodeflawsCFLPyGStatementDataset, k, device):
        super(TopKStatmentExplainer, self).__init__(model, loss_func, dataset, device)
        self.iterator = TopKStatementIterator(model, dataset, k, device)

    def get_data(self, instance):
        return instance[0]

    def get_perturber(self, data) -> torch.nn.Module:
        return StatementGraphPerturber(data).to(device)

    def explain(self):
        return super().explain(self.iterator)


def from_data_to_nx(graph, perturber: StatementGraphPerturber, metadata: CodeflawsCFLStatementGraphMetadata):
    g = nx.MultiDiGraph()
    for i, x in enumerate(graph.xs):
        x = x.reshape(-1)
        if i == 0:
            # Then the node graph is ast
            for j, node in enumerate(x):
                g.add_node(f"ast_{j}", ntype=metadata.t_asts[int(x[j].item())], explain_weight=perturber.xs_weights[i][j].item())
        elif i == 1:
            # Then the node graph is test
            for j, node in enumerate(x):
                g.add_node(f"test_{j}", ntype=metadata.t_tests[int(x[j].item())], explain_weight=perturber.xs_weights[i][j].item())
        # each row of x is a data of a node
    # Translate from each edge type to the corresponding edge
    for i, es in enumerate(graph.ess):
        # i is the ith etype
        src_type, etype, dst_type = metadata.meta_graph
        for j in range(es.shape[1]):
            src_node = f"{src_type}_{es[0, j].item()}"
            dst_node = f"{dst_type}_{es[1, j].item()}"
            g.add_edge(src_node, dst_node, etype=etype[i], explain_weight=perturber.ess_weights[i][j].item())
    return g

def get_args():
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument("--model_path", type=str, required=True)
    parser.add_argument("--save_path", type=str, default="explain_pyg_codeflaws_pyc_cfl_stmt_level")
    parser.add_argument("--k", type=int, default=10)
    parser.add_argument("--loss_func", type=str, default="total_loss_size_stmt_entropy")
    parser.add_argument("--device", type=str, default='cuda')
    return parser.parse_args()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    args = get_args()
    device = torch.device(args.device if torch.cuda.is_available() else 'cpu')
    nx_dataset = CodeflawsCFLNxStatementDataset()
    pyg_dataset = CodeflawsCFLPyGStatementDataset()
    meta_data = CodeflawsCFLStatementGraphMetadata()
    t2id = {'ast': 0, 'test': 1}
    exec(f"loss_func = {args.loss_func}", globals(), locals())
    infl_extractor = InflExtractor(where_node(), where_edge(where_node(), where_node()), 0.1, 0.3)
    model = MPNNModel_A_T_L(dim_h=64,
                            netypes=len(meta_data.meta_graph),
                            t_srcs=[t2id[e[0]] for e in meta_data.meta_graph],
                            t_tgts=[t2id[e[2]] for e in meta_data.meta_graph],
                            n_al=len(meta_data.t_asts),
                            n_layers=5,
                            n_classes=2).to(device)
    model.load_state_dict(torch.load(args.model_path))
    explainer = TopKStatmentExplainer(model, loss_func, pyg_dataset, args.k, args.device)
    save_dir = args.save_path
    os.makedirs(save_dir, exist_ok=True)
    for i, (((graph, stmt_nodes), target_stmt_idx), perturber) in enumerate(explainer.explain()):
        target_node = f"ast_{stmt_nodes[target_stmt_idx].item()}"
        g = from_data_to_nx(graph, perturber, meta_data)
        infls = infl_extractor.extract_infl_structure(g, target_node)
        # Dump this g
        nx.write_gpickle(infls, os.path.join(save_dir, f"{i}.gpickle"))
        # Visualize with dot
        nx.drawing.nx_pydot.write_dot(infls, os.path.join(save_dir, f"{i}.dot"))

Integration Engineer assignment
Background / Intro
One of the the most basic and key features of MailerLite is managing subscribers. Someone needs to receive your beautiful newsletters created on MailerLite so you need to have a great way to handle that data. There are a few different ways how it can be achieved:

Add subscriber form in our web app
Public HTTP API endpoint
Custom and unique web form or landing page
Other services which are integrated with MailerLite using our API
All the ways mentioned above are based on using a single service dedicated to the management of subscribers.

Task: API Integration
Your main task is to create a simple PHP application for managing the subscribers of a MailerLite account via the MailerLite API.

You can find more information about the MailerLite API at https://developers.mailerlite.com

Features
Your PHP application should have the following features:

Validating and saving an API key:

Validate an account's API key against the MailerLite API
Save the valid key in the database.
Next time the user opens the page, load the key from the database
Showing the subscribers of an account:

Use DataTables (https://datatables.net/) to display all the subscribers of the account. The email, name, country, subscribe date and subscribe time of each subscriber should be displayed on the table (5 fields).
An account may have millions of subscribers so it is not efficient to load and show all of them at once. For that reason, you should implement pagination and only load a few subscribers for each page. To implement this feature, please use the server side data source of the DataTables library.
It should be possible to use the search field to search for subscribers by email and to change the number of subscribers displayed per page.
Do not do any direct calls to the MailerLite API from the frontend. Instead, proxy all requests through the backend of your application.
The subscribe date should be in the day/month/year format while the subscribe time should be in the 24-hour format with leading zeroes.

Creating subscribers:

Create a page with a form that asks the user to type the email, name and country of a subscriber.
By pressing submit, your backend creates a new subscriber using the MailerLite API.
API errors are handled gracefully by your application (e.g. subscriber already exists, invalid email, etc.) and an error is shown to the user
On success, a message is shown to the user.
Deleting a subscriber:

A button should exist next to each subscriber in the DataTable that deletes the subscriber via a MailerLite API call.
Like before, do not call the MailerLite API from the frontend but proxy the request through your backend.
No need to show a popup to confirm the delete, just delete the subscriber.
Optional bonus: handle everything (delete and table refresh) without a page redirect.
Editing a subscriber:

Clicking on a subscriber email in the DataTable opens the a form that allows the editing of the name and country subscriber fields only.
On save, the subscriber information is saved to MailerLite via an API call.
General Requirements
Laravel framework
HTTP JSON API
Validating requests
Instructions how to run a project on local environment running PHP 7.4, MySQL 5.x and the latest Chrome browser
PSR-2 compliant source code
Write tests for the backend of your app
Task II: Finish Line
Create a public repository on GitHub for your application source code, push it and send us the link

Do not develop:
User authentication
CSRF
Database migrations (just provide the .sql file)

On souhaite réaliser une application répartie pour gérer des équipements et des services présents dans un réseau IP. 
Pour ce faire, sur le modèle de SNMP, chaque machine à gérer fera fonctionner un agent disposant d’informations(sur le service ou la machine) que l’on pourra consulter et modifier au travers d’un protocole simple depuis une application de gestion (le manager). De plus, lors d’un événement (de type « mise à jour » d’information), les agents devront envoyer une alerte (trap) aux managers intéressés.
Dans une version plus aboutie, les managers pourront être hiérarchisés de façon à permettre une gestion multi-utilisateur et plus efficace des équipements et services.
Les communications entre les entités composant l’application répartie pourront, au choix, être réalisées en RMI
on a effectuer la version 1 et 2 et il nous reste la version 3:
Version 1 - Protocole de consultation
A cette étape on a mis en place les agents et les managers.
On gère uniquement les opérations de consultation et de modification (type get et set) pour une information 
simple (nom de l’équipement, adresse de l’équipement ou du service par exemple).
Version 2 - Mise en place d’une MIB
A cette étape on a mis en place une base de donnée MIB_Data.txt d’information de gestion sur le modèle 
d’une MIB SNMP.
On ajoutera l’implantation de l’opération « get-next » qui permet de parcourir cette base de donnée.
Version 3 - Mise en place des traps
Les agents doivent maintenant pouvoir prévenir les managers au travers d’évènements sur le modèle des traps SNMP. Il faudra aussi, à cette étape, prévoir une opération d’abonnement des agents aux traps.

“””
class Abstract_Strategy(ABC):
    """ Abstract class for Strategy
    All strategies must inherit from this class"""
    def __init__(self, parameters: dict = None, id_strategy: int = None,
                 callback: callable = None, set_basic: bool = True):
        if callback is None:
            self.callback = _callback_default
        else:
            self.callback = callback
        self.parameters = parameters
        if 'limit_save_values' in self.parameters:
            self.limit_save_values = self.parameters['limit_save_values']
        else:
            self.limit_save_values = 0
        self.ticker = parameters['ticker']
        self.active_contract = self.ticker
        if 'tickers_to_feeder' not in self.parameters:
            self.tickers_to_feeder = self.ticker  # tickers for feed the strategy by events, default is ticker
        if 'ticker_broker' in self.parameters: # ticker for send orders to broker
            self.ticker_broker = self.parameters['ticker_broker']
            self.active_contract =  self.ticker_broker
        self.quantity = parameters['quantity']
        self.number_of_contracts = 0  # number of contract in the position
        self.active_role = False # True if the strategy is on Role mode
        self.roll_contracts = 0 # number of contracts to roll
        self.id_strategy = id_strategy
        self.type_trading = 'financial' # by default
        self.n_events = 0  # number of events received
        self.n_orders = 0  # number of orders sent
        self.position = 0  # position in the strategy, 1 Long, -1 Short, 0 None
        self.inicial_values = False  # Flag to set inicial values
        self.saves_values = {'datetime': [], 'position': [], 'close': []}
        # Equity handler of the strategy
        if 'save_equity_vector_for' in self.parameters:
            self.save_equity_vector_for = self.parameters['save_equity_vector_for']
        else:
            self.save_equity_vector_for = ['close_day', 'order']
        self.bar_to_equity = False
        if 'bar' in self.save_equity_vector_for:
            self.bar_to_equity = True
        if 'name' not in self.parameters:
            self.name = 'strategy'
        else:
            self.name = self.parameters['name']

        fees = 0
        if 'fees' in self.parameters:
            fees = self.parameters['fees']
        slippage = 0
        if 'slippage' in self.parameters:
            slippage = self.parameters['slippage']
        point_value = 1
        if 'point_value' in self.parameters:
            point_value = self.parameters['point_value']
        if 'base_currency' in self.parameters:
            base_currency = self.parameters['base_currency']
        else:
            base_currency = {'ticker': 'USD', 'value': 1}  # default base currency if the product is in USD already

        self.equity_hander_estrategy = Equity(ticker=self.ticker, asset_type='crypto', fees=fees, slippage=slippage,
                                              point_value=point_value, id_strategy=self.id_strategy,
                                              base_currency=base_currency)

        if set_basic:
            self.add_bar = self._add_event_example

    def update_equity(self, event: dataclass):
        """ Update equity """
        is_day_closed = False
        if event.event_type == 'bar':
            update = {'quantity': 0, 'price': event.close, 'datetime': event.datetime}
        elif event.event_type == 'order':
            quantity = event.quantity
            if event.action == 'sell':
                quantity = -quantity
            update = {'quantity': quantity, 'price': event.price, 'datetime': event.datetime}
        elif event.event_type == 'tick' and event.tick_type == 'close_day':
            update = {'quantity': 0, 'price': event.price, 'datetime': event.datetime}
            is_day_closed = True
        # update equity
        self.equity_hander_estrategy.update(update)
        self.equity_hander_estrategy.fill_equity_vector()
        # update equity day
        if is_day_closed:
            self.equity_hander_estrategy.fill_equity_day()

    def get_order_id_sender(self):
        """ Return order_id_sender """
        return f'{self.id_strategy}_{self.n_orders}_{dt.datetime.utcnow().strftime("%Y%m%d%H%M%S")}'


    def send_roll(self, roll_event: dataclass, type_roll: str='close'):
        """ Send roll event to the broker """
        self.active_contract = roll_event.description
        if type_roll == 'close' and self.active_role is False: # close position on the old contract
            self.active_role = True
            self.roll_contracts = self.number_of_contracts
            quantity = abs(self.roll_contracts)
            if quantity > 0:
                action = 'buy'
                if self.roll_contracts > 0:
                    action = 'sell'
        elif type_roll == 'open' and self.active_role: # open position on the new contract
            self.active_role = False
            quantity = abs(self.roll_contracts)
            if quantity > 0:
                action = 'sell'
                if self.roll_contracts > 0:
                    action = 'buy'
            self.roll_contracts = 0
        if quantity > 0:
            self.send_order(ticker=self.ticker, price=roll_event.price, quantity=quantity,
                                action=action, type='market', datetime=dt.datetime.utcnow())

    def send_order(self, price=None, quantity=None, action=None, ticker=None, type='market', datetime=None,
                   match_name=None, ticker_id=None, selection_id=None, cancel_seconds=None, unique_name=None,
                   selection=None, contract=None):
        """ Send order to exchange or broker """
        if self.type_trading in ['financial', 'crypto']:
            # contract tracking
            if action == 'buy':
                self.number_of_contracts += quantity
            elif action == 'sell':
                self.number_of_contracts -= quantity
            # update position tracking
            if self.number_of_contracts < 0:
                self.position = -1
            elif self.number_of_contracts > 0:
                self.position = 1
            elif self.number_of_contracts == 0:
                self.position = 0
            # if contract is None, name is active_contract
            if contract is None:
                contract = self.active_contract

            sender_id = self.get_order_id_sender()
            order_id_sender = self.get_order_id_sender()
            order = Order(datetime=datetime,
                          dtime_zone='UTC', ticker=ticker, action=action,
                          price=price, quantity=quantity, type=type, sender_id=sender_id,
                          order_id_sender=order_id_sender, contract=contract)
            self.callback(order)
            self.n_orders += 1
            if self.limit_save_values > 0:  # save values by limit, this way it is more efficient
                if len(self.saves_values['datetime']) > self.limit_save_values:
                    for k in self.saves_values.keys():
                        self.saves_values[k] = self.saves_values[k][-self.limit_save_values:]
            # update equity
            self.update_equity(order)

        elif self.type_trading == 'betting':
            bet = Bet(datetime=datetime, dtime_zone='UTC', ticker=ticker,
                      selection=selection, odds=price, quantity=quantity,
                      match_name=match_name, ticker_id=ticker_id,
                      selection_id=selection_id, action=action,
                      cancel_seconds=cancel_seconds, unique_name=unique_name
                      )

            self.callback(bet)  # send bet to betting platform

    def add_event(self, event: dataclass):
        """ Add event to the strategy and apply logic """
        pass

    def get_saved_values(self):
        """ Return values saved """
        return self.saves_values

    def _add_event_example(self, event: dataclass):
        """ Basic logic for testing purposes """
        if event.event_type == 'bar':
            self.n_events += 1
            if self.n_events % self.parameters['entry'] == 0:
                self.send_order(ticker=event.ticker, price=event.close, quantity=self.parameters['quantity'],
                                action=self.parameters['inicial_action'], type='market', datetime=event.datetime)
                # Change action
                if self.parameters['inicial_action'] == 'buy':
                    self.parameters['inicial_action'] = 'sell'
                elif self.parameters['inicial_action'] == 'sell':
                    self.parameters['inicial_action'] = 'buy'
            # save values
            self.saves_values['datetime'].append(event.datetime)
            self.saves_values['position'].append(self.position)
            self.saves_values['close'].append(event.close)

        else:
            pass

tic("cluster analysis")


numberParticipants <- nrow(finalData)

# create distance matrix from the maxdiff data
distanceMatrix <- as.matrix(dist(finalData, method = "euclidean"), nrow = numberParticipants)


# define here for test purposes whether weighting is enabled or not
# in the final script this information is passed by the app
# TODO: choose if weighting should be applied
weighting <- FALSE


# this step is only for test purposes to have weight vector
if (weighting == TRUE) {
  weightVector <- runif(numberParticipants, 0.5, 1.5)
} else {
  weightVector <- rep(1, numberParticipants)
}

# this is the sample size used for mean calculations
sampleSize <- sum(weightVector)

# step 1: run hierarchical analysis
hcAnalysis <- hclust(as.dist(distanceMatrix), method = "ward.D2", members = weightVector)

# Step 2: calculate indexes for different number of clusters
kMedoidsRange <- wcKMedRange(distanceMatrix, 3:7, weights = weightVector, method = "PAMonce")

# Step 3: estimate recommended model
# include multiple criteria to define optimal cluster solution
# criterion 1: must be ranked #1 by at least one index
# criterion 2: sample size must be balanced, i.e. no sample smaller than 10%
# criterion 3: test profiles/significant differences (TBD how)

# criterion 1: being ranked first
indexRankedFirst <- as.data.frame(summary(kMedoidsRange)) %>%
  .[-c(7,9), ] %>%    # filter out pseudo-r2 as it is always higher for more clusters
  setNames(c("clusterNumber", "index")) %>%
  group_by(clusterNumber) %>%
  mutate(count = n()) %>% # count how often each cluster number is ranked first
  distinct(clusterNumber, count) %>% # have only one row per cluster number
  arrange(desc(count)) # sort by number of votes


# criterion 2: creating balanced solutions
balancedClusters <- c()
minClusterSize <- 0.075 # the minimum size in % for each cluster

for (clusters in indexRankedFirst$clusterNumber) {
  clusterIndex <- clusters
  kMedoidsIndex <- wcKMedoids(distanceMatrix, clusterIndex, weights = weightVector, npass = 1, initialclust = hcAnalysis,
                                 method = "PAMonce", cluster.only = FALSE)
  clustersParticipantIndex <- kMedoidsIndex$clustering
  clusterSizeIndex <- data.frame(cbind(weightVector, clustersParticipantIndex)) %>% group_by(clustersParticipantIndex) %>% 
                      summarise(size = sum(weightVector) / sampleSize)
  balancedClusters[clusters] <-  all(clusterSizeIndex >= minClusterSize)
}

# store remaining models in a new object by assessing the index of the balanced solutions
balancedModelsNumber <- which(balancedClusters == TRUE)

# if all solutions fail the test, ignore it and use all models
if (length(balancedModelsNumber) == 0) {
  balancedModelsNumber <- which(balancedClusters == FALSE)
}
  
  
# criterion 3: create significant differences
# suggestion 1: average number of spikes per segment (vs. total)


spikesOverviewList <- list()
for (clusters in balancedModelsNumber) {
 
  clusterIndex <- clusters
  kMedoidsIndex <- wcKMedoids(distanceMatrix, clusterIndex, weights = weightVector, npass = 1, initialclust = hcAnalysis,
                              method = "PAMonce", cluster.only = FALSE)
  clustersParticipantMedoid <- kMedoidsIndex$clustering
  clusterNamesMedoid <- unique(clustersParticipantMedoid)
  clustersParticipantIndex <- plyr::mapvalues(clustersParticipantMedoid, clusterNamesMedoid, c(1:clusters))
  clusterNamesIndex <- c(1:clusters)
  meansDataIndex <- cbind(finalData, clustersParticipantIndex, weightVector)
  spikesOverviewList[[clusters]] <- list()
  
  for (clusterName in clusterNamesIndex) {
    spikesOverviewList[[clusters]][[clusterName]] <- list()
    for (variable in names(meansDataIndex)[1:(ncol(meansDataIndex) - 2)]) {
    
    # create vectors for cluster to test
    segmentProfileByClusterIndex <- meansDataIndex %>% filter(clustersParticipantIndex == clusterName) %>% pull(variable)
    weightsClusterIndex <- meansDataIndex %>% filter(clustersParticipantIndex == clusterName) %>% pull(weightVector)
    # create vectors for the rest of the sample
    segmentProfileTotalIndex <- meansDataIndex %>% filter(clustersParticipantIndex != clusterName) %>%  pull(variable)
    weightsTotalIndex <- meansDataIndex %>% filter(clustersParticipantIndex != clusterName) %>%  pull(weightVector)
    # test for significance
    spikeSignificance <- wtd.t.test(x = segmentProfileByClusterIndex, y = segmentProfileTotalIndex, 
                                    weight = weightsClusterIndex, weighty = weightsTotalIndex,
                                    samedata = FALSE)$coefficients[["p.value"]]
    spikesOverviewList[[clusters]][[clusterName]][[variable]] <- spikeSignificance <= 0.05
    }
  }
}

# compute average number of spikes  per segment and choose index with maximum
# if two models are identical, choose the one with the lower index (done automatically)
averageNumberSpikes <- c()

for (segment in balancedModelsNumber) {
  numberSpikes <- length(which(unlist(spikesOverviewList[segment]) == TRUE))  / segment
  averageNumberSpikes[segment] <- numberSpikes
}

recommendedNumberClusters <- which.max(averageNumberSpikes)

recommendedNumberClusters <- 3


# run final model again

clustersEstimation <- wcKMedoids(distanceMatrix, recommendedNumberClusters, weights = weightVector, npass = 1, initialclust = hcAnalysis,
                                method = "PAMonce", cluster.only = TRUE)

clustersFinal <- plyr::mapvalues(clustersEstimation, unique(clustersEstimation), c(1:recommendedNumberClusters))

# compute means by cluster and bind together with cluster size
meanDataFinal <- cbind(finalData, clustersFinal, weightVector)
clusterMeansFinal <- meanDataFinal %>% group_by(clustersFinal) %>% summarise_at(vars(variableNames), funs(weighted.mean(.,weightVector))) %>% t()
clusterSizeFinal <- meanDataFinal %>% group_by(clustersFinal) %>% summarise(size = sum(weightVector) / sampleSize) %>% t()
clusterOverview <- rbind(clusterSizeFinal, clusterMeansFinal[-1, ])

# compute means for total sample
totalSampleMeans <-  meanDataFinal %>% summarise_at(vars(variableNames), funs(weighted.mean(.,weightVector))) %>% t()
name <- "total"
size <- 1
totalSampleOverview <- rbind(name, size, totalSampleMeans)

# bind together participant ids with cluster memberhsip
participantData <- cbind(participantID, clustersFinal)

# bind together total means with cluster means for complete overview

resultsOverview <- cbind(totalSampleOverview, clusterOverview)

toc()



write.csv(participantData, "clustersParticipant.csv", row.names = FALSE)
write.xlsx(resultsOverview, "resultsOverview.xlsx", row.names = TRUE)


The code appears to be performing a cluster analysis, specifically using the methods of Hierarchical Clustering and K-Medoids.It starts by reading in two sheets from an excel file "Need Prioritizer.xlsx" as bestCounts and worstCounts and creating a finalData by subtracting the last column of worstCounts from the last column of bestCounts.Next, it renames the columns of finalData with a set of specified column names.It then initializes a few variables such as weighting and sampleSizeIt performs the following steps for the cluster analysis:step 1: runs a Hierarchical Clustering on the finalData, using the ward.D2 method and the weightVectorstep 2: uses the wcKMedRange() function to calculate indexes for different number of clusters (3-7) using PAMonce methodstep 3: estimates the recommended model using 3 criteria:criterion 1: the model must be ranked #1 by at least one indexcriterion 2: the sample size must be balanced, with no sample smaller than 10%criterion 3: test profiles/significant differencesIt then extracts the clusterNumber and count of the models which are ranked first according to the criterion 1.It creates a balanced solution by checking if the clusters meet the minimum size of 7.5% as defined by criterion 2.It then returns the final cluster solution based on the criteria 1, 2 and 3.Finally, it calculates the time taken for the cluster analysis.

Write code that solves the following:

--- Day 1: Calorie Counting ---
Santa's reindeer typically eat regular reindeer food, but they need a lot of magical energy to deliver presents on Christmas. For that, their favorite snack is a special type of star fruit that only grows deep in the jungle. The Elves have brought you on their annual expedition to the grove where the fruit grows.

To supply enough magical energy, the expedition needs to retrieve a minimum of fifty stars by December 25th. Although the Elves assure you that the grove has plenty of fruit, you decide to grab any fruit you see along the way, just in case.

Collect stars by solving puzzles. Two puzzles will be made available on each day in the Advent calendar; the second puzzle is unlocked when you complete the first. Each puzzle grants one star. Good luck!

The jungle must be too overgrown and difficult to navigate in vehicles or access from the air; the Elves' expedition traditionally goes on foot. As your boats approach land, the Elves begin taking inventory of their supplies. One important consideration is food - in particular, the number of Calories each Elf is carrying (your puzzle input).

The Elves take turns writing down the number of Calories contained by the various meals, snacks, rations, etc. that they've brought with them, one item per line. Each Elf separates their own inventory from the previous Elf's inventory (if any) by a blank line.

For example, suppose the Elves finish writing their items' Calories and end up with the following list:

1000
2000
3000

4000

5000
6000

7000
8000
9000

10000
This list represents the Calories of the food carried by five Elves:

The first Elf is carrying food with 1000, 2000, and 3000 Calories, a total of 6000 Calories.
The second Elf is carrying one food item with 4000 Calories.
The third Elf is carrying food with 5000 and 6000 Calories, a total of 11000 Calories.
The fourth Elf is carrying food with 7000, 8000, and 9000 Calories, a total of 24000 Calories.
The fifth Elf is carrying one food item with 10000 Calories.
In case the Elves get hungry and need extra snacks, they need to know which Elf to ask: they'd like to know how many Calories are being carried by the Elf carrying the most Calories. In the example above, this is 24000 (carried by the fourth Elf).

Find the Elf carrying the most Calories. How many total Calories is that Elf carrying?
